Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Pulsed Subsidies on Island Food Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spatial and temporal variation in the availability of resources can have profound effects on the structure and the dynamics of natural communities. Resource pulses are short-term increases in resource availability; on islands in the Bahamas, seaweed deposited during large storms represents an important resource pulse, or subsidy, for predatory lizards. This project will combine experimental and observational studies to determine how seaweed subsidies shape island communities, which are comprised mainly of plants, herbivores, web spiders, and lizards. Major goals are to understand how community responses differ with the frequency and magnitude of seaweed pulses, the ability of consumers such as lizards to aggregate in areas with pulsed resources, the indirect effects of resources on predators' alternative prey, and the various pathways - for example, predation versus nutrient enrichment - by which these complex interactions are manifested. Experiments will be initiated that manipulate both seaweed pulses and lizard densities to address these goals. These field studies will be integrated with mathematical modeling in order to develop a general theory of community responses to resource pulses.

Through partnerships with the University of California at Davis Bohart Museum of Entomology and Friends of the Environment in the Bahamas, the project will integrate outreach and education for K-12 students. Researchers will give classroom presentations, train teachers to integrate science in their curriculum, and develop and distribute teaching materials via the web. The research will strengthen an international partnership via collaboration with a Japanese scientist. It also will contribute to the development of a diverse national scientific community and workforce by involving undergraduate and graduate students from under-represented groups in the research process. Results will contribute to a firmer understanding of the ecological consequences of rapid environmental change. As anthropogenic disturbances such as overfishing and eutrophication facilitate shifts towards algae-dominated marine ecosystems, and as climate change causes more frequent and intense Atlantic storms, the effects of marine resource pulses or subsidies on island and coastal communities are predicted to intensify.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to examine how food webs on land respond to pulses of resources from the sea. We studied a system of small, uninhabited rocky islands in The Bahamas that receives occasional storm-driven inputs of seaweed. In order to test hypotheses that emerged from earlier work in this and other systems, we experimentally manipulated the availability of seaweed across 52 experimental units, which served as replicate ecological communities. These units were carefully chosen and manipulated to allow us to examine the role of lizard predators, island size, community isolation, and other factors in our analysis.

We collected many kinds of data on soil, plants, insects, spiders, and lizards, including detailed measurements of plant growth, herbivory, stable isotope ratios, lizard habitat use and diet, and soil nutrient availability. The findings of these projects are still emerging, but key results to date include the following:

1) Seaweed subsidies increased lizard densities, root growth, and soil nutrient availability within a year. Observed changes in herbivory are likely to result from changes in lizard behavior and fertilization.

2) Lizards on islands receiving multiple seaweed subsidies eat more marine-derived prey. If lizards are absent, spiders also show an increased marine contribution to their diet; this pattern was not apparent on islands where lizards were present or on "mainland" units.

3) Lizards on islands responded numerically to subsidy, whereas lizards on mainlands did not. The response on subsidized islands is likely driven by increased survival of adults, with larger adult populations resulting in more offspring produced overall.

4) Lizard numerical responses may also be constrained by drought conditions that varied over the course of the study.

5) Seaweed subsidies may rescue island populations. Three out of four populations on islands without subsidy went extinct during the course of the experiment.

6) Lizard-driven trophic cascades on islands appear to be initially weakened by seaweed addition (presumably due to changes in diet and behavior that reduce predation pressure on herbivores), but subsequently strengthened by seaweed addition (presumably due to increased lizard abundance on seaweed-addition islands compared to islands with no seaweed).

These findings show how seaweed inputs affect ecological communities via both aboveground (lizard diet shifts and lizard numerical responses) and belowground (fertilization) pathways. The multiplicity of pathways operating in these simple systems illustrate the potential complexity of ecological effects, and the importance of differences in the relative timing of these pathways. This study builds upon previous studies that have examined resources pulses to test specific hypotheses about differences in the temporal pattern of a resource inputs and the relative importance of different pathways of potential effects using a replicated experiment on whole-island communities. We have applied novel methods in several of our experiments, and have conducted several studies

This project has also had broader impacts that benefit society and advance desired societal outcomes. Throughout this project, we collaborated with Friends of the Environment (FOE), a local Bahamian non-profit conservation and education organization. We developed an educational poster to build awareness of Bahamian lizard biodiversity, which we made available to FOE for distribution in local schools. We also supported the development of a research field station at FOE, and the establishment of East Abaco Creeks National Park, a new national park that protects much of our field site. This international collaboration has helped us strengthen a valuable and mutually beneficial research and education partnership. We also provided research experience and mentorship to many undergraduate and graduate students throughout this project, broadening participation in science.
